nodes.bodyText: maybe this test could have a more descriptive name?

we did not find any good names for them, that why it is like this in all Xpath tests.
@esilkensen , do you have suggestions ?
Ah, this sounds good to me then - I didn’t realize it was the same in all other tests too.

it does not mean it is good in all others :) , we just do not know better alternatives.
reason of this tests is not to validate Xpath correctness and make sure it works in general, that is why names are so general. If in future we will run into problems of xpath for particular Check then we will create test like testOnInnerClasswithAnnotationAndXxxxxx.
@AmrDeveloper , please add one more test, we need at least two tests.
@romani Done but CI not passed again !

I don’t think the pitest failure is transient/flaky, but I tried looking at how to resolve it yesterday and didn’t find the answer...
A common approach could be to take the line of code and the mutation that is surviving and construct a test that fails when that mutation is present, but the confusing thing here is pitest lists two identical mutations for the same line with one surviving, so I’m not sure what the report is telling us.

but CI not passed again !

it is even better, at least behavior is stable. It is sad that it blocks your PR. Looks like we run into pitest bug, so we need to find a workaround....
